citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of the genus Kroppenstedtia gen. nov.

Kroppenstedtia (Krop.pen.sted′ti.a. N.L. fem. n. Kroppenstedtia named in honour of Reiner M. Kroppenstedt, a German microbiologist, who has contributed significantly to the field of bacterial taxonomy).
Cells are aerobic, Gram-positive and chemoorganotrophic.
Thermotolerant growth occurs between 25 and 50 °C, and at pH 5.0–8.5.
Substrate and aerial mycelia are formed, both producing chains of arthrospores and heat-resistant endospores, the latter are formed singly on unbranched sporophores.
Major fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0 and anteiso-C15 : 0.
The cell wall peptidoglycan contains ll-DAP and is of type A3γ ll-DAP–Gly (Schleifer & Kandler, 1972).
Diagnostic sugars are not detected in whole-cell hydrolysates, implying cell-wall chemotype I sensu Lechevalier & Lechevalier, 1970.

The phospholipid pattern predominantly consists of diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylglycerol, indicating phospholipid pattern type PII sensu (Lechevalier et al., 1977).
The DNA G+C content of the type strain of the type species is 54.6 mol%.
The type species is Kroppenstedtia eburnea.
